headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to David Barden with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go next to David Barden with Bank of America.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, I -- if I could, just 2 clarifications. So number one, John, so just on the revenue recognition for CAF II, I guess, inasmuch as the CAF II funding is going to be a step-function increase in the regulatory receipts starting next quarter, is th
componenttext: So I guess, I -- if I could, just 2 clarifications. So number one, John, so just on the revenue recognition for CAF II, I guess, inasmuch as the CAF II funding is going to be a step-function increase in the regulatory receipts starting next quarter, is that what we should be modeling in, as a step-function increase in revenues starting in 3Q and going forward? And then I think you mentioned there weren't going to be a lot of additional expenses. So it kind of sounds like there's a step-function increase in EBITDA. That was kind of point one. And then point two, I think that you were saying that over the life of the program, over and above what you received in USF, that incremental amount of money will cover all the CapEx spending in order to meet the requirements. I think that was clarification number two. And then just on the last piece is, on the bond deal that you're -- or debt financing that you're working on. I think one of the issues for the equity over the last little while has been that there's been this feedback loop where the bond market's anticipating a bond raise, so the bond yields go up, and that puts pressure on equity, and that informs an opinion for the bond market. And getting that deal done, I think will be potentially very positive for the equity. Could you kind of elaborate on your strategy for addressing that kind of part of the funding program? It would be helpful.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me first start in terms of the rev rec on CAF. Yes, it will flow through subsidy revenue in the second half of this year, and you will see that step-function increase in EBITDA really related to the regulatory revenue stream. We will -- we conti
componenttext: Sure. Let me first start in terms of the rev rec on CAF. Yes, it will flow through subsidy revenue in the second half of this year, and you will see that step-function increase in EBITDA really related to the regulatory revenue stream. We will -- we continue to see in positive momentum in our customer revenue stream, and this will step it up from a regulatory revenue perspective. I will say, too, that in the back half of this year, we'll also be recognizing the amount that we get as a true-up payment as well as certain unwind of the frozen support. So in total for the year is we will have more than the $283 million of the CAF II support because it also will include some unwind, but that will be in the back half of the year. Think about this, Dave, proportionately over, call it, a 5-month period, because we'll get the true-up payment we anticipate this month here, so we'll see probably 2/5 of that impact in the third quarter and then the remaining 3/5 in Q4.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Dave, let me -- the increment of the CapEx versus frozen support and our ability to meet the requirements under CAF II. We've had our engineering teams working on this issue now for the better part of 5, 6 months. And we feel very comfortable that if
componenttext: And Dave, let me -- the increment of the CapEx versus frozen support and our ability to meet the requirements under CAF II. We've had our engineering teams working on this issue now for the better part of 5, 6 months. And we feel very comfortable that if you look at the incremental funding that we'll get above the frozen support level that, that meets all of our needs necessary to upgrade these 650,000 to 660,000 households. So we're very comfortable with that. Starting this late in the year, we'll focus on, I think, some low-hanging fruit. But then you'll see us ramp up and address some of those unserved areas as we get into 2016 where we think there's a lot of opportunity to take share and really drive higher ARPCs as we bring customers onto a broadband product.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dave, the last point -- question you asked with respect to the debt financing and timing, I think you're absolutely right. I think the market would like to understand the total shape of what we're doing, and we're making good progress at it. We had a huge
componenttext: Dave, the last point -- question you asked with respect to the debt financing and timing, I think you're absolutely right. I think the market would like to understand the total shape of what we're doing, and we're making good progress at it. We had a huge step in June as we did the equity raise. We're in the market right now with respect to the next layer of our debt financing. And as to the remainder, we'll continue to be opportunistic here. As Dan indicated now, with our target of roughly March 31 of closing, we still have plenty of time, 7 months, that we have in the debt markets, but we will be opportunistic as we get it done. And we think that the best impact for us, with respect to how we trade in the market, quite frankly, is our performance -- is our continuing performance, and we think Q2 bodes well for us.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Kevin Smithen with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll go next to Kevin Smithen with Macquarie.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wondered if you could talk a little bit about pricing initiatives. You had very strong ARPF [ph] or whatever your acronym you're using. And I apologize for -- there's a lot of different ones going around the industry now. How you sort of think about inc
componenttext: I wondered if you could talk a little bit about pricing initiatives. You had very strong ARPF [ph] or whatever your acronym you're using. And I apologize for -- there's a lot of different ones going around the industry now. How you sort of think about incremental price hikes and the normal annual price hikes for Verizon FiOS. Will those continue during this transition period? And how do you sort of price your broadband versus theirs over the next -- till the closing?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kevin, the -- from a pricing perspective, probably the single biggest area that we made changes in was in the Connecticut market, and we did that to ensure that we would have a price in the market that was both competitive and prevented customers from mig
componenttext: Kevin, the -- from a pricing perspective, probably the single biggest area that we made changes in was in the Connecticut market, and we did that to ensure that we would have a price in the market that was both competitive and prevented customers from migrating to more acquisition pricing. The benefits that you see on ARPC were partially associated with that as well as customers moving to higher speeds and also customers taking our Frontier Secure product set. So it's a combination of all 3 of those. As we look at the Verizon properties that we're acquiring, we will continue to pass through the content price hikes. We also will be pricing -- passing those through on our legacy FiOS markets as well as Connecticut. You'll see us do that generally in the same time frame as most others in the first half of any calendar year. And as we look at the pricing that Verizon has in the market, again we'll be replicating that pricing in those markets towards the end of the year and rolling that out in our existing markets. But more importantly, we will not have any changes to those price points or bundles or business processes, so we eliminate the potential for a similar migration effect that occurred in Connecticut. And I think that's a key point in our change in our integration planning.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just in the normal course with Verizon, if for -- if the deal doesn't close until after the typical price hikes at the beginning of the year, would that -- would those price hikes still take effect? Or were they weighed in how you decide what to do up
componenttext: And just in the normal course with Verizon, if for -- if the deal doesn't close until after the typical price hikes at the beginning of the year, would that -- would those price hikes still take effect? Or were they weighed in how you decide what to do upon closing?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that they would move forward with the normal course of operating their business. So if that hike is in the first quarter, that would happen in the first quarter.
componenttext: I think that they would move forward with the normal course of operating their business. So if that hike is in the first quarter, that would happen in the first quarter.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Frank Louthan with Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Frank Louthan with Raymond James.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Back to the CAF issue. Can you give us some details on the CAF I results? Where did some of the costs come in relative to what you're expecting for CAF II and the penetration you've gotten? And any insight on what Verizon is considering doing with the CAF
componenttext: Back to the CAF issue. Can you give us some details on the CAF I results? Where did some of the costs come in relative to what you're expecting for CAF II and the penetration you've gotten? And any insight on what Verizon is considering doing with the CAF money they've been offered in the states that you're acquiring?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Frank. The CAF I funding, there's a wide variety of cost per household passed, depending upon where those census blocks were. So we anticipate the same kind of phenomenon in the CAF II as we look at it. Our engineering teams have very detailed models
componenttext: Yes, Frank. The CAF I funding, there's a wide variety of cost per household passed, depending upon where those census blocks were. So we anticipate the same kind of phenomenon in the CAF II as we look at it. Our engineering teams have very detailed models. They're based off of not just CAF I, but also the 14 states that we upgraded previously with Verizon. So we have a huge amount of experience in upgrading those markets, and that's what's informed our confidence on being able to accomplish the goals of CAF II within the incremental CapEx above the current frozen support levels. We've seen nothing that's really changed our mind on that. We were able to actually accomplish all of the CAF I build-out below what the original allocation of the CAF I funds were. So we feel very good about that, and we're also very bullish based on the experience and the take rates that we've seen in the CAF I areas for what we can expect from knock-on effect for customers taking the product after we enable those areas. So many of these customers, their only solution today is either a dial-up, which seems crazy for us to be talking about that, but also a satellite-based broadband. So obviously, our product, even at a fully loaded cost, would be significantly better than either of those alternatives, and we're expecting some really nice development on that.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, a couple of follow-up questions. One, looking at the business services in Connecticut, looked like a nice inflection there based on what we think the trends have been of late. Wondering, Dan, maybe you could just talk a little bit about what you'
componenttext: I guess, a couple of follow-up questions. One, looking at the business services in Connecticut, looked like a nice inflection there based on what we think the trends have been of late. Wondering, Dan, maybe you could just talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the business services side in Connecticut and how sustainable that trend may be. Maybe how much break down a little bit. How much could be from customer wins versus some of the pricing actions that may have taken place in 1Q? And then maybe just a question for John on EBITDA. Obviously, you talked a bit about CAF II will mean on the revenue and EBITDA side of the equation. But wondering if we sort of strip out CAF II, if you could talk a little bit about what the trajectory for EBITDA might look like in the second half. I think Dan mentioned increased headcount, which I think we've seen for a couple of quarters now tied to Frontier Secure. That's something that should continue. And just how do we think about some of the puts and takes on sort of the organic EBITDA going forward?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Scott. On the Connecticut business services, we are very bullish on Connecticut commercial services. In fact, it's one of our best performing markets. And when we look at it, it really had nothing to do with pricing actions. It had everything to do
componenttext: Okay, Scott. On the Connecticut business services, we are very bullish on Connecticut commercial services. In fact, it's one of our best performing markets. And when we look at it, it really had nothing to do with pricing actions. It had everything to do with winning customers and taking business. The predominant services that we're selling are Ethernet. In fact, it's been an incredibly complementary addition to the entire workflow around that. It's probably our most successful Ethernet market to date, and we continue to see that each and every month. So we're very, very bullish on Connecticut, continue to see good performance there.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then Scott, with respect to EBITDA, we don't guide on EBITDA. I will just say that we are very optimistic about the trends that we have, including maintaining our margins as we go forward.
componenttext: And then Scott, with respect to EBITDA, we don't guide on EBITDA. I will just say that we are very optimistic about the trends that we have, including maintaining our margins as we go forward.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have the ability, per our purchase and sale agreement, Phil, to use the FiOS brand as well as the technology for an additional 5 years in all of our legacy markets as well as all the acquired markets. During that 5-year time frame, we will develop our
componenttext: We have the ability, per our purchase and sale agreement, Phil, to use the FiOS brand as well as the technology for an additional 5 years in all of our legacy markets as well as all the acquired markets. During that 5-year time frame, we will develop our own product set that's exactly the same and focused on Quantum or the IMG, and we'll be able to take advantage of this as kind of a leapfrog forward. So it'll be exactly the same for 5 years, and then we'll make subtle differences and make that our own going forward.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And what kind expense should we be thinking about there? Any kind of ramp-up? Or is that built into the existing numbers?
componenttext: And what kind expense should we be thinking about there? Any kind of ramp-up? Or is that built into the existing numbers?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's built into our existing plants. All acquisition will be really focused on kind of the Quantum product set going Q4 forward. And then next year, as customers migrate away from the older technology, whether it's set-top boxes or want to upgrade to Qu
componenttext:
That's built into our existing plants. All acquisition will be really focused on kind of the Quantum product set going Q4 forward. And then next year, as customers migrate away from the older technology, whether it's set-top boxes or want to upgrade to Quantum, then we might see some expense, but we're not anticipating a very large bump there.
Well, I just -- I want to thank everyone for joining us this morning. In closing, I'd say we had very solid results in the second quarter, both in legacy and Connecticut portions of the business. We're continuing to lay the groundwork and making progress towards completion of the Verizon acquisition. And the entire company is intensely focused on increasing shareholder value, and we believe we have significant opportunities ahead of us. So again, thank you for joining our call today, and we look forward to updating you again on the third quarter.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
