headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. Just one follow-up on the churn commentary. Do you -- have you seen any change in October trends in the legacy market? Or are you implementing any different strategies to lower that churn?
componenttext: Okay, got it. Just one follow-up on the churn commentary. Do you -- have you seen any change in October trends in the legacy market? Or are you implementing any different strategies to lower that churn?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We do have a number of different strategies that our contact centers have been utilizing, really throughout the summer, as they try and battle some of the churn that does happen during that seasonal period. I think that in the fourth quarter, we absolutel
componenttext: We do have a number of different strategies that our contact centers have been utilizing, really throughout the summer, as they try and battle some of the churn that does happen during that seasonal period. I think that in the fourth quarter, we absolutely see churn come back down. It usually occurs after October. So really, November and December is when we see the biggest drops.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from David Barden with Bank of America.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from David Barden with Bank of America.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I had a couple of follow-ups. So first, John, just to make sure we're all in the same page with respect to the guidance. Could you clarify whether the free cash flow guide is free cash flow or adjusted free cash flow as you've been defining it her
componenttext: I guess I had a couple of follow-ups. So first, John, just to make sure we're all in the same page with respect to the guidance. Could you clarify whether the free cash flow guide is free cash flow or adjusted free cash flow as you've been defining it here? And then the second one is, I think, every fourth quarter for the last couple of years, we get on the phone and talk about business services being weak because of the promotional kind of redo that happens every quarter. Could you kind of -- you've given us some revenue guide, but could you map that issue out a little bit for us and what we should expect for 4Q? And if I could, one last one. Just as it relates to the merger closing, California is the last pole in the tent. Could you kind of discuss a little bit about what their asks are and your comfort level that they're within bounds of reasonableness in terms of the financials related to the transaction?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Dave, with respect to leveraged free cash flow or that guidance range, that is, as we've always provided, on as adjusted basis. Just to clarify. So that's equivalent to how we've been reporting it. With respect to business services or promotional
componenttext: Okay. So Dave, with respect to leveraged free cash flow or that guidance range, that is, as we've always provided, on as adjusted basis. Just to clarify. So that's equivalent to how we've been reporting it. With respect to business services or promotional activity, we don't see anything major in the quarter. We've had our Amazon Prime promotion. That's really added to -- got great traction with our residential customers. So we don't see anything unusual in the quarter. I think the dynamics that we see as we go forward -- continuing pickup on our broadband net adds, we do see some of the secular headwinds still in our voice revenue streams. And we will have a little bit of step-down with respect to our wireless backhaul revenue. But other than those items, nothing has really changed with respect to our business as we go forward. Our alternate channels continue to drive great activity in SME and more business there. So we're optimistic about the path for SME revenue stream.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: David, this is Dan. On the California part of your question, it's been a long process. It's been very collaborative. The commission held a number of public comment hearings really around the entire service area. At this point, our philosophy has been to w
componenttext: David, this is Dan. On the California part of your question, it's been a long process. It's been very collaborative. The commission held a number of public comment hearings really around the entire service area. At this point, our philosophy has been to work collaboratively with the different parties in the transaction. I think we've had a lot of success on that. In that way, we really align some of the requirements to meet the public needs benefit test with what our business strategy is for the state. So as I sit here today, all of those agreements, although bring substantial benefit to the systems at California, are also aligned with what we want to do from a business perspective. That includes broadband expansion in some areas, which we had really forecasted in our cash flow models; use of CAF II funds in various parts of the State of California as dictated by the CAF II rules; speed upgrades, which we had planned to do in some of the copper markets; enhanced reporting about supplier and diversity supplies. And really, we are at a point now after reaching, essentially, agreements with the vast majority, if not all of the parties, that the commission will draft their order, and then we'll see what the final requirements are by the California commission. We still expect to have that draft order over the next several weeks, and that we're still anticipating an approval in the late December time frame.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, and I appreciate that, Dan. And John, I'm sorry, just to totally make sure I'm thinking about this the right way. Your free cash flow guidance includes the expenses related to the preferred dividends and the interest expense on the bonds that were
componenttext: Great, and I appreciate that, Dan. And John, I'm sorry, just to totally make sure I'm thinking about this the right way. Your free cash flow guidance includes the expenses related to the preferred dividends and the interest expense on the bonds that were raised for the Verizon transaction, correct?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Our leveraged free cash flow, as we defined it and as you'll see in the schedules, that excludes the preferred dividend and the incremental interest on the acquisition-related financing. And that's how we consistently define that.
componenttext: No. Our leveraged free cash flow, as we defined it and as you'll see in the schedules, that excludes the preferred dividend and the incremental interest on the acquisition-related financing. And that's how we consistently define that.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Scott Goldman with Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Scott Goldman with Jefferies.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, following up on the expense side of the equation. I noticed headcount was up a bit 2Q into 3Q. I'm wondering if that's tied into the Verizon integration activities that you guys are undertaking or perhaps elsewhere, and whether that was a factor
componenttext: I guess, following up on the expense side of the equation. I noticed headcount was up a bit 2Q into 3Q. I'm wondering if that's tied into the Verizon integration activities that you guys are undertaking or perhaps elsewhere, and whether that was a factor in the expenses, the non-one-timee type of expenses that we saw in 3Q. Also, on the expense side, I think you mentioned that channel mix produced some higher costs. I think you mentioned that was lumpy. Just curious how we should think about that channel mix and maybe the go-to-market strategy and what that implies about the expense side going forward. And then just lastly, on the CAF II, I think you've provided some good details. Just wondering if you can maybe share how much CapEx was related to CAF II in the quarter and what your expectations are for this year and for future years on the CAF II CapEx side.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Scott, I'll start off, and then let Dan pick it up. With respect to headcount, really most of that headcount was related to our Frontier secure strategic partnership support. We've been driving great incremental revenue with our strategic partners,
componenttext: Great. Scott, I'll start off, and then let Dan pick it up. With respect to headcount, really most of that headcount was related to our Frontier secure strategic partnership support. We've been driving great incremental revenue with our strategic partners, and so we add -- -- had some headcount to support that offering. It's proven to be very profitable for us from a revenue perspective and driving incremental EBITDA, so the headcount was primarily around that. And it did add to a sequential increase in the quarter as compared to Q2 in our expense.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott. And on the channel mix, as you rather pointed out, it was up slightly differently. We tried some different things this summer, and I think it was reflective in the strong broadband performance that we were able to post. Historically, we've had
componenttext: Yes, Scott. And on the channel mix, as you rather pointed out, it was up slightly differently. We tried some different things this summer, and I think it was reflective in the strong broadband performance that we were able to post. Historically, we've had -- we tried to target a mix that was more heavily-based on inbound calls through our contact centers, and that's generally our lowest-cost channel. In this case, we tried to meet customers in a different place, not use some of the traditional marketing techniques and relied more heavily on some of our partners from the alternate channels. And we saw very good results. It did come with a slightly higher cost. But again, as John pointed out, that would change quarter-to-quarter. We would target a lower-cost mix as we get into Q4, which is historically when we start to see call volumes pick up more substantially in our contact centers and we get more of a mix from that channel. As far as CAF II goes, we really got the funds in and we started. But we really only spend about $2 million in the quarter. We'll start to ramp that, but we'll quickly get shut down as we get into October as certain municipalities prevent us from opening roads or really starting any progress. So we'll see more of a ramp-up as we get into 2016. And we'll provide more guidance on that as we get through the end of the fourth quarter.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we'll hear from Frank Louthan with Raymond James.
componenttext: Moving on, we'll hear from Frank Louthan with Raymond James.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to clarify, can you quantify some of the impact of some of the floods and the fires and that sort of thing? And then, just looking at your customer adds. So your net loss of residential customers in the 30,000 range and adding about 27,000 broadband,
componenttext: Just to clarify, can you quantify some of the impact of some of the floods and the fires and that sort of thing? And then, just looking at your customer adds. So your net loss of residential customers in the 30,000 range and adding about 27,000 broadband, can you give us an idea of that mix? I mean, what is sort of the economics of that trade-off there and the types of customers that you're losing maybe? And how many of those broadband customers are existing customers that are adding broadband versus completely new customers you're getting in the market?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Frank, I -- Dan and I are -- still want to make sure we clarify the second -- your second question. As to the first one, storm cost probably added an incremental $5 million to $6 million in the quarter sequentially as compared to Q2. That's both primarily
componenttext: Frank, I -- Dan and I are -- still want to make sure we clarify the second -- your second question. As to the first one, storm cost probably added an incremental $5 million to $6 million in the quarter sequentially as compared to Q2. That's both primarily overtime-related costs as well as some outside services. But the restoration costs were pretty substantial. As you know, the flooding was quite significant in the Midwest. But perhaps, can you just sort of repeat again your second question? We want to make sure that we heard it correctly.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you had a nice broad add -- gains in broadband. To what extent is that offsetting -- how are the economics of these broadband customers tracking now with sort of your residential customers that you're sort of net losing? Are you gaining broadband share
componenttext: So you had a nice broad add -- gains in broadband. To what extent is that offsetting -- how are the economics of these broadband customers tracking now with sort of your residential customers that you're sort of net losing? Are you gaining broadband share in the marketplace? To what extent are those -- what is the mix of brand-new customers taking broadband versus existing customers upgrading? And is it sort of a net outflow of customers? And what's the economic trade-off?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll start, and John will probably jump in, Frank. So we're still seeing very strong market share growth, especially in our legacy areas. As I pointed out, year-to-date, 75% of the market we're expressing growth. One of the nice things that we see is cont
componenttext: I'll start, and John will probably jump in, Frank. So we're still seeing very strong market share growth, especially in our legacy areas. As I pointed out, year-to-date, 75% of the market we're expressing growth. One of the nice things that we see is continued trend to have close to 1/3 of our activations have Frontier Secure activated on the account. That gives us a nice ARPC lift and -- of about $10 per sub. The trend that we've experienced historically of R1 losses and customers who were at that lower end of the portfolio continues. During the summer, we do tend to see an uptick in customers that might have double play or in some cases, triple play, as they move or make their decisions about moving their homes to a different location. So during that period, we do see an uptick in some of the higher ARPC customer losses. But I would say, the general trend that we've talked about historically of lower-end customers leaving and then us replacing them with broadband customers that are taking other services continues.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Frank, just to add. As in prior quarters, we had a slight decline in net residential customers. And what we've seen is that loss has been mostly from voice-only customers. That's been our continuing trend. Again, we continue to add broadband customers. Th
componenttext: Frank, just to add. As in prior quarters, we had a slight decline in net residential customers. And what we've seen is that loss has been mostly from voice-only customers. That's been our continuing trend. Again, we continue to add broadband customers. Those accounts increase. And more of our new customers that we add are in -- take broadband services. Probably, 91% of our gross adds in the quarter were at least a double play, if not a triple play customer.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Barry McCarver with Stephens Inc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Barry McCarver with Stephens Inc.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, as we think about your integration efforts of the Verizon assets, can you talk about what the near-term performance of those assets have looked like for you? And then just secondly, you talked about some incremental efficiencies from scale after
componenttext: I guess, as we think about your integration efforts of the Verizon assets, can you talk about what the near-term performance of those assets have looked like for you? And then just secondly, you talked about some incremental efficiencies from scale after you acquire those assets and get them fully integrated. Any way you could kind of quantify what you're seeing there? Is that a couple of hundred basis points of margin over a few years or less than that?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Barry, with respect to the asset performance of those 3 states, we'll be providing that information later on this quarter. Once we have full data from Verizon, we'll be filing that. But I think you've seen their results that they announced earlier,
componenttext: Sure. Barry, with respect to the asset performance of those 3 states, we'll be providing that information later on this quarter. Once we have full data from Verizon, we'll be filing that. But I think you've seen their results that they announced earlier, a few weeks ago. But with respect to these properties, we'll be providing those in particular. With respect to margin improvement or costs, again, I would just highlight, as Dan will jump in here, that we remain very confident in our Day 1 cost reduction. And that's a net $525 million and $700 million by the end of the third year. We're seeing opportunities for, actually, that to be higher on the first day and in total for the $700 million to be accelerated faster than the end of the third year. And the work that we're doing all -- as we go over each week and each month continues to reinforce what we're forecasting.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Barry, from the different things that are pluses for us as we go through this integration, it has been an extensive amount of investment in a number of things that really move us much closer to a Verizon way of doing business, is the best way I can d
componenttext: Yes. Barry, from the different things that are pluses for us as we go through this integration, it has been an extensive amount of investment in a number of things that really move us much closer to a Verizon way of doing business, is the best way I can describe it. So a lot more self-service for customers so that they can manage accounts, they can manage the services that they purchase from us. They have the ability to interface with us with different choice points. All of those really equate over the long term to improvements in our cost structure. Provisioning and our provisioning platforms that we'll be utilizing for our flagship products are all being enhanced and changed. Our dispatch system and how we manage our technicians around the country. Testing and diagnostic tools that are available to both our technicians as well as our help desk and contact centers. And really, moving more to a VoIP least course [ph] routing approach towards LD carriage, which is something that Verizon had moved to in the past. So when you combine all of those things that we're investing to be ready for these 3 states and you apply them to our historic properties, you get a real opportunity to make some substantial changes.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And moving on, we'll hear from Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And moving on, we'll hear from Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Spencer for Simon. Quick question on cash taxes. You guys lowered guidance again. Why -- what are the drivers there? And any implications for '16? And then what's the latest you guys are hearing on potential for bonus depreciation?
componenttext: It's Spencer for Simon. Quick question on cash taxes. You guys lowered guidance again. Why -- what are the drivers there? And any implications for '16? And then what's the latest you guys are hearing on potential for bonus depreciation?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Spencer, I think with respect to cash taxes, it's some more planning work that we've been able to do. All along the way, there are various specific elements that we've worked through that gives us a great level of comfort on this reduced level of ca
componenttext: Sure. Spencer, I think with respect to cash taxes, it's some more planning work that we've been able to do. All along the way, there are various specific elements that we've worked through that gives us a great level of comfort on this reduced level of cash taxes. As we've previously indicated for 2016, we had done a range estimate of $275 million to $325 million, and that was done mid sort of third quarter. I will say, however, that bonus depreciation would improve that and some further planning elements. So I'm going to hold on providing any updated cash tax guidance until we get into 2016. But I think suffice it to say is, we do feel comfortable with that number being at the upper end of the range. But we'll add more specifics as we get into next year.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Spencer, this is Dan. From what we're hearing, we are hearing that there's a very good possibility that a Bill could be reached in compromise that would extend it, at a minimum, 2 years. That's what we're hearing at this point, but it would be towards
componenttext: And Spencer, this is Dan. From what we're hearing, we are hearing that there's a very good possibility that a Bill could be reached in compromise that would extend it, at a minimum, 2 years. That's what we're hearing at this point, but it would be towards the latter part of this year.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Spencer, so the impact of that, the benefit of that, we would see in 2016 since we think we've pretty much completed our cash tax payments for 2015. So any '15-specific benefit, we would see that in 2016.
componenttext: Yes, Spencer, so the impact of that, the benefit of that, we would see in 2016 since we think we've pretty much completed our cash tax payments for 2015. So any '15-specific benefit, we would see that in 2016.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Gregory Williams with Cowen and Company has our next question.
componenttext: And Gregory Williams with Cowen and Company has our next question.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's just about the Verizon acquisition. You guys have mentioned in the past that this is a bit of a unique acquisition and that Verizon's committed to a certain level of OpEx and CapEx spend. And I was hoping you could provide a little color on that comm
componenttext: It's just about the Verizon acquisition. You guys have mentioned in the past that this is a bit of a unique acquisition and that Verizon's committed to a certain level of OpEx and CapEx spend. And I was hoping you could provide a little color on that commitment. Is it KPIs or metrics that need to achieved or a certain dollar amount in certain categories? And how much discretion do you have in the way in which they spend it?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg, the real metric is around a minimum level of CapEx that's required based upon historic trends, and they really are still running the business. They are making investments and we're watching, and we're very pleased with the investments they're m
componenttext: Yes, Greg, the real metric is around a minimum level of CapEx that's required based upon historic trends, and they really are still running the business. They are making investments and we're watching, and we're very pleased with the investments they're making at this point. Those include upgrades to both their fiber and their copper facilities as well as selectively upgrading things like microwave towers. So we feel pretty good about the working relationship at this point. We feel very good about the investments they're making, and we're very comfortable that the business continues to perform very well. And we look forward to seeing the results from Verizon over the next couple of weeks.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, to -- also to be more specific, with respect to OpEx, their commitment is really around marketing expenditure within OpEx. So it's that plus our -- plus CapEx.
componenttext: Greg, to -- also to be more specific, with respect to OpEx, their commitment is really around marketing expenditure within OpEx. So it's that plus our -- plus CapEx.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll hear from James Moorman with D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: We'll hear from James Moorman with D.A. Davidson.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: A quick question in terms of, what do you kind of see in SME in terms of Connecticut? It seems like you guys had a really good quarter last year. And what are you seeing in terms of competition in Connecticut sort of on the business front?
componenttext: A quick question in terms of, what do you kind of see in SME in terms of Connecticut? It seems like you guys had a really good quarter last year. And what are you seeing in terms of competition in Connecticut sort of on the business front?

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the SME front, we see certainly robust competition on the very small end that are more attributable to cable competitors that are in the different markets. At the very high end, which we don't necessarily play as much in the enterprise space -- I
componenttext:
Yes. On the SME front, we see certainly robust competition on the very small end that are more attributable to cable competitors that are in the different markets. At the very high end, which we don't necessarily play as much in the enterprise space -- I mean, we do in certain markets. So that seems to be where more of the higher-end service and some of the other competitors are playing. We feel very good about the total solution that we offer. Our sweet spot is more in the high-end, small and the medium and the lower-end enterprise. Those areas we'll bring real value to our customers in providing turnkey solutions as well as a robust network that can interconnect their local facilities. So it might be a health care customer. It could be a trucking customer. So those are places we've played well. We're doing quite well in there providing solutions. And the other area that I would just say is we're starting to see some traction in our Ethernet on our wholesale side. So you asked about SME. But I think in the future, you'll see continued growth in that segment as well. 
So in closing, we, once again, had a very solid result this quarter, both in the legacy and Connecticut portions of the business. In the third quarter, we were successful in completing a broad range of significant milestones for the acquisition of California, Texas and Florida markets, and our integration activities remain on track. The entire company remains intensely focused on increasing shareholder value, and we believe we have significant opportunities ahead of us. So thank you for joining us on our call today, and we look forward to updating you again on the fourth quarter.

headline: Frontier Communications Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude our conference for today. We thank you for your participation.
componenttext: And ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude our conference for today. We thank you for your participation.
